solution with the service.
This is agenda for today's session.

I'm gonna be discussing about
what operational analytics is

and what observability is
and where do they fit in.

And I'm gonna discuss some few
use cases for observability

and what all the data or
pillars of observability is.

And finally, I'm gonna

Service that helps you to

What is operational analytics?
It is not a new field

it is a field that evolved
from operation research

from industrial manufacturing
three or four decades ago.
The aim of operation research
was to improve the business efficiency

and similarly the aim
of operational analytics
which applies to-- which means

that applying operational
research to modern day

computing systems is to
improve business efficiency
under customer experience and value.

Traditionally, operational
analytics has been done

using batch systems where
you process a large volume
of data and then get some insight

from it that helps you to
make some business decision.
The aim of operational analytics
is to remove this manual process
and to use missions in the process

so they can make the decisions
faster and also in some way
shape or form in an automated fashion.

Operational analytics falls
in three distinct categories,
the first of which is what is called
descriptive analytics.

When you look at a complex
system, you should--

you need to be able to
describe what the system is
in first place so that you
can understand and characterize behavior.
All the activities that you do is covered
under descriptive analytics.
Next is called the predictive analytics.
So once you know what the system is
and you understand its behavior

then you can predict how a
system is going to behave.
All the activities that you do
comes into predictive analytics.

Finally, what is called a
prescriptive analytics means
that once you know what a system is

and how it behaves, and
you can predict what it is,
if some issue were to happen

then you can be prescriptive
about a solution

either in an manual
fashion or you can even

use the machine to take
some automated decision.

That's what all the
activity that you do there
is called prescriptive analytics.
So where does observability fit in?

It fits into the category of
this descriptive analytics
that helps you to understand the behavior

of a complex system using
some data that you gather
from the system itself.
So what is observability?
Observability, as I mentioned before

just like operational
analytics, is a measure

of how well you can
understand the behavior

of a system or the
internal states of a system
from the knowledge of its external outputs

without knowing how the
system itself behaves.
So observability is just to, is a measure
of how well you can infer the state

so that you can predict
its behavior and finally

be prescriptive if any
issues were to happen.

So what are some of the use
cases for observability?
The first and the foremost use cases

in the field of microservices
and container as

monolithic applications gets
broken down into microservices,

you need to be able to
know what is happening
within the system.

Or for example, you want to
know how we request (indistinct)

to the entire system under
(indistinct) service.

So that's one emerging use case
where observability is used.
The next is what we call, like to call it
as a digital experience monitoring.

So this is where you have
applications that interacts

with user and you would like
to know what the user is doing,
what the user behavior is, and what part

of the systems are
users more interested in

that helps you to make
business decisions based
on those data, or it can improve
the overall efficiency of a system.

The next one is what is
called this operation center

or AIOps or DevOps, where
you can use observability
to reduce your meantime to knowledge.
That is if an issue were to happen

then you can quickly
identify what the issue is

and once you know that, then
you can formulate a resolution

and the time it takes to
formulate a resolution,
which is termed as meantime to resolution.
The last application of data lakes,

last application of
observability is in data lakes
is where when you process a large volume

of data and you have
this large complex system
in tracking feature and you'd like to know
what the state of the system is in
and how you can characterize the behavior
so as to improve the data processing.

So what data can you collect
from a system to improve the,

to understand the internal
states of a system.

The first and the foremost
is what is called as SLOCs.

These are time series
events that happened,

or that happen that helps
you to get an insight
into what is happening in the system.

These can be from your
applications or infrastructure
or other parts of system.

Next is metrics, which gives
you a numerical measurement
of your system state

or the resource utilization
of a system itself.

And finally the last is what
is called as a trace data.
It allows you to track a request

as it enters your complex
system and as it goes

through it and finally
returns after being serviced.

So that's it's, that's
the last component of
observability itself.
So now let's look at architecture

or what are all the components
that are involved, associated

and the services that
you can use to achieve

or accomplish this observability
within your system.

The first and the foremost
is to the ability to

collect these three
different types of data,

the logs, metrics and
traces and open telemetries

in a vendor-agnostic, or in a
programming environment-agnostic,
or your infrastructure-agnostic way.

It's an open-- it's aiming
to be an open standard.
So OpenTelemetry is a set of tools,

STKs, and agents that helps
you to collect these data.

So you will collect it and
you will use other tool
what is called this DataPrepper.
It allows you to change this

or transform this data into
a form that can be consumed

by a service like Amazon
OpenSearch Service.
We all know there are agent-based tools

like fluentbit that allows
you to collect metric

and log data from your
applications and send it

to next layer or next part
of the architecture itself

which is the storage
layer. Where you can send--

so DataPrepper and
fluentbit sends these logs
and metrics and traces

to storage services like
Amazon OpenSearch Service

services that are available

that allows you to

Amazon Managed Service

for Prometheus, where

You can use, again,
Amazon OpenSearch Service

for visualization, or
there are other services

You can use the metrics data coming

to Amazon Service for Prometheus,

and log data coming from
Amazon OpenSearch Service.

So we look at some of
the components that built
inside Amazon OpenSearch Service itself.

The first and foremost
is what is called as

observant UI that has

The next part of the system is

through relationship

The last is what is called as trace groups

this aggregates similar
traces into a trace group

So the unique thing about
